output.rationale: This is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure (along with PM10) and respiratory hospital admissions using distributed lag non-linear models (a time-series approach). The study reports quantitative associations between PM2.5 and admission risk for respiratory diseases (asthma and COPD). While the abstract doesn't explicitly state RR/OR with confidence intervals, it describes significant associations and patterns, suggesting effect estimates are reported. The study meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and asthma-related ED visits using time-series analysis (mixed-effects quasi-Poisson regression on daily counts). Asthma exacerbations requiring ED visits qualify as respiratory emergency department visits. While the abstract does not explicitly report an RR/OR with CI, the methods indicate appropriate statistical modeling that would generate such estimates, and the results show significant associations (P<10-4). The study meets all major inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is one of the exposures analyzed, (3) outcome is asthma hospitalization which is a respiratory hospitalization, (4) uses time-stratified case-crossover design, (5) reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs (0.31% increase per 1-μg/m3 PM2.5, 95% CI 0.24-0.37%), and (6) published in English. Although multiple pollutants were analyzed, PM2.5 effects are clearly reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 was the primary pollutant (62% of days) and pollutant-specific analyses were conducted, (3) outcome includes both respiratory ED visits and hospitalizations for asthma, (4) case-crossover design, (5) reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals, and (6) published in English. While the primary exposure measure is AQI, the study explicitly analyzes PM2.5-specific effects and identifies PM2.5 as the dominant pollutant.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcomes include respiratory hospitalizations (32 respiratory diagnoses), (4) uses time-stratified case-crossover design, (5) reports associations/effect estimates with PM2.5 for respiratory outcomes (31 of 32 respiratory outcomes were positively associated with PM2.5), and (6) published in English. While the study also examines cardiovascular outcomes, it clearly analyzes respiratory hospitalizations as a major component.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly examined as one of the exposures, (3) the outcome is hospital admissions for respiratory disease, (4) it uses a time-series design with DLNM, (5) it reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals (PM2.5: RR=1.030, 95% CI: 1.012-1.049), and (6) it appears to be published in English. Although multiple air pollutants are analyzed, PM2.5 is specifically included with quantitative effect estimates.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using case-crossover design, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures, (3) outcome includes both respiratory ED presentations and hospitalizations for bronchiolitis, (4) time-stratified case-crossover design is specified, (5) odds ratios with quantitative estimates are reported (>10% increased risk for PM2.5), and (6) published in English. The study analyzes multiple pollutants (NO2, PM2.5, PM10) but PM2.5 is explicitly included with effect estimates.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using time series analysis, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures, (3) the outcome is respiratory hospitalizations (acute upper respiratory infections), (4) it uses a time series study design with distributional lagged nonlinear models, (5) it reports relative risk values with 95% confidence intervals for PM2.5 (RR = 1.0247, 95% CI: 1.0092, 1.0405), and (6) it is published in English. While it also examines other pollutants (PM10, SO2, NO2), PM2.5 is specifically included and analyzed.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study explicitly identified as case-crossover design, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcomes include both respiratory hospitalizations and emergency department visits, (4) study design is case-crossover, (5) multiple odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals are reported, and (6) the article is in English. While the population is specific (childhood cancer survivors), this does not disqualify it from the review as it still addresses the core association between PM2.5 and respiratory hospitalizations.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study; (2) exposure includes PM2.5 alongside PM10 and NO2; (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalizations for bronchiolitis; (4) study design is case-crossover; (5) reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals (PM2.5: OR=1.04 [1.02-1.06]); (6) published in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design; (2) the exposure includes fine particulate matter (PM2.5); (3) the outcome is respiratory hospitalizations in children; (4) the study design is case-crossover; (5) it reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals (e.g., OR=1.004 [0.955-1.056] overall, and stratified estimates); and (6) it appears to be published in English. Despite also examining oxidant gases and particle constituents, PM2.5 is a primary exposure of interest.

While this study meets several inclusion criteria (time-series design, PM2.5 exposure, has RR estimates), the outcome is hospitalization specifically for SARS-CoV-2/COVID-19 infection rather than general respiratory hospitalizations. COVID-19 hospitalizations represent a specific infectious disease outcome that differs from the broader category of respiratory hospitalizations typically examined in PM2.5 systematic reviews. The review appears to focus on general respiratory morbidity rather than COVID-19-specific outcomes.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory (asthma) emergency department visits. It reports rate ratios with 95% credible intervals for PM2.5 (RR=1.016, 95% CI: 1.008-1.025). The outcome is asthma ED visits, which falls under respiratory emergency department visits. All inclusion criteria are met.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure, reports both respiratory ED presentations and hospital admissions as outcomes, and provides quantitative effect estimates (incidence rate ratios) with 95% confidence intervals for a 10 μg/m3 increase in PM2.5.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures, (3) the outcome is respiratory disease hospitalizations, (4) it uses a time-series study design, (5) it reports quantitative effect estimates including relative risk and percentage increases in hospitalization risk (8.3% and 12.1% for temperature effects are mentioned, and positive lag effects for PM2.5 are described), and (6) the abstract is in English. While the study also examines other pollutants and temperature, PM2.5 is specifically included and analyzed.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) It is an original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly studied as an exposure, (3) respiratory disease hospitalizations are the outcome, (4) time-series analysis with GAM was used, (5) the abstract indicates that risk associations were quantified (PM2.5 'associated with increased risks'), suggesting effect estimates were reported, and (6) the article is in English. While PM10 was also studied, PM2.5 is clearly included as one of the exposures analyzed.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study; (2) exposure is smoke PM2.5; (3) outcome includes respiratory hospitalizations (acute respiratory infections, pneumonia, COPD, asthma, and other respiratory diseases); (4) study design is case-crossover (extended version); (5) reports relative risk with 95% confidence intervals; (6) published in English. While it also examines cardiovascular outcomes, the respiratory outcomes are clearly analyzed and reported separately.

This is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations (URTI). It uses a time-series design (generalized additive Poisson model analyzing daily data), reports quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals (0.84% increase per 10 μg/m³, 95% CI 0.05-1.64%), and examines hospital admissions and emergency room visits. All inclusion criteria are met.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is analyzed as one of multiple exposures with specific effect estimates reported, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalization (asthma and COPD admissions), (4) time-series study design explicitly stated, (5) reports risk ratios with 95% CIs for PM2.5 (asthma: 95% CI 0.981-1.148; COPD: 95% CI 0.966-1.019), and (6) published in English. Although the main findings are for NO2 rather than PM2.5, the study provides quantitative PM2.5 effect estimates for respiratory hospitalizations, making it eligible for inclusion.

While this study meets most inclusion criteria (original epidemiological study, PM2.5 exposure, respiratory hospitalization outcome, quantitative effect estimates with CI reported), it is described as a 'retrospective cohort study' rather than a time-series or case-crossover design. The study design criterion is specific and restrictive, requiring either time-series or case-crossover methodology. Although the study uses distributed lag models with daily data which shares some analytical similarities with time-series approaches, the explicitly stated cohort design does not meet the specified inclusion criteria.

While this is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design with PM2.5 exposure (from wildfire smoke) and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, the primary outcomes are cardiovascular and cerebrovascular ED visits, not respiratory hospitalization/ED visits. Although respiratory conditions were examined and showed an association (RR 1.18), they appear to be a secondary outcome used as a positive control rather than the primary focus of the study. The study does not meet the outcome inclusion criterion as it focuses on cardiovascular and cerebrovascular events.

This is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design (daily data with distributed lag models and quasi-Poisson regression) that examines PM2.5 exposure and reports quantitative effect estimates (RR with 95% CI) for respiratory ED visits, specifically pneumonia. While the study also examines cardiovascular outcomes, it includes respiratory outcomes (pneumonia, COPD/asthma) that meet inclusion criteria. The study reports RR = 1.071 (95% CI: 1.025-1.118) for pneumonia ED visits associated with PM2.5 exposure.

While this study examines PM2.5 exposure and pneumonia (respiratory) hospitalizations with quantitative effect estimates, it uses a prospective cohort design rather than the required time-series or case-crossover design. The inclusion criteria specifically limit study designs to time-series or case-crossover studies.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory emergency room visits using a generalized additive model (consistent with time-series design). It reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals (e.g., RR = 1.011, 95%CI: 1.002, 1.020). The study focuses on short-term PM2.5 effects with lag structures, which is characteristic of time-series analysis. Emergency room visits are equivalent to emergency department visits and qualify as the outcome of interest.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study using case-crossover design, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures analyzed, (3) Outcome is respiratory hospital admissions, (4) Case-crossover design is appropriate, (5) Reports percentage change in odds with 95% CI (effect estimates for PM2.5: 1.2% increase per 10 μg/m3), (6) Published in English. While multiple pollutants are analyzed, PM2.5 is specifically included and reported.

While this is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure and reporting quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals, the outcome is hospitalization for rheumatoid arthritis-associated interstitial lung disease (RA-ILD), which is a specific autoimmune condition affecting the lungs, not general respiratory hospitalizations. RA-ILD is an extrapulmonary manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis rather than a primary respiratory condition caused by air pollution exposure. The review specifically targets respiratory hospitalizations, not autoimmune disease hospitalizations with pulmonary involvement.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design to examine the association between PM2.5 exposure and pediatric respiratory emergency department visits (including asthma/wheeze, bronchitis, pneumonia, and upper respiratory infections). The study reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals and is published in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 exposure explicitly studied, (3) respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits for asthma and COPD as outcomes, (4) time-stratified case-crossover design, (5) reports excess rates with 95% confidence intervals (e.g., ER = 2.1%, 95% CI = 0.7%, 3.6%), and (6) appears to be published in English

While the title mentions 'hospitalization', the abstract clearly describes the outcome as 'outpatient visits' for upper respiratory tract infections, not hospitalizations or ED visits. The study uses a generalized additive model (time-series design) with PM2.5 exposure, but does not meet the outcome criteria of respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits.

This is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and both respiratory ED visits and hospitalizations. The study uses a time-series design with Poisson regression, reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals for respiratory outcomes (RR=1.25 for respiratory disease EDVs, RR=1.18 for CLRD), and appears to be published in English. It meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 (among other pollutants) and respiratory hospitalizations for AECOPD. It reports quantitative effect estimates (RR with 95% CI) for PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations. Although the study also examines temperature interactions and other pollutants (NO2, PM10), PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the analyzed exposures. AECOPD hospitalization is a specific type of respiratory hospitalization that meets the outcome criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design to examine the association between PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospital admissions in Kuwait. The study reports quantitative effect estimates (1.61% increase per 10 μg/m3 increase in PM2.5) with 95% confidence intervals. The exposure is clearly PM2.5, the outcome is respiratory hospitalizations, and the study uses an appropriate time-series regression model with distributed lag models.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using case-crossover design, (2) exposure is source-specific PM2.5, (3) outcomes include respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits for influenza and pneumonia, (4) case-crossover design as specified, (5) reports excess rates with 95% CIs (e.g., ER = 9.2%; 95% CI: 4.3%, 14.3%), and (6) appears to be published in English. The study examines respiratory infections (influenza and pneumonia) which are respiratory conditions requiring hospitalization/ED visits.

This is an original time-series study using generalized additive model with quasi-Poisson regression examining the association between PM2.5 (among other pollutants) and emergency department visits for upper respiratory tract infection. The study reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals (5.302% increase per 10 μg/m3 PM2.5, 95% CI: 3.202, 7.445). Upper respiratory tract infection falls under respiratory conditions requiring ED visits. All inclusion criteria are met.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study using generalized additive model; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of multiple exposures; (3) Outcome is respiratory hospitalization (pneumonia and asthma); (4) Study design is time-series based on the methodology (aggregate hospitalization data over time with lag analysis using GAM); (5) Reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals (2.22% increase per 10-unit PM2.5 increase, 95%CI: 0.64%, 3.82%); (6) Published in English. The study analyzes multiple pollutants but PM2.5 is one of them with separate effect estimates reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome is asthma emergency room admissions (respiratory hospitalization/ED visit), (4) time-series study design, (5) reports quantitative effect estimate with 95% CI (7.2% increase, 95% CI 1.7-13.1%), and (6) published in English. No exclusion criteria apply.

This is an original case-crossover study examining PM2.5 (among other pollutants) and respiratory hospitalizations (interstitial lung disease admissions are respiratory hospitalizations). The study reports odds ratios with 95% CIs. While the abstract emphasizes SO2 and NO2 results, PM2.5 is explicitly listed as one of the exposures assessed, making it eligible for inclusion.

This study meets most inclusion criteria: it is a time-series study examining PM2.5 (among other pollutants) and respiratory hospitalizations with effect estimates. However, the abstract only reports RR estimates for NO2, ozone, and noise - not for PM2.5, despite PM2.5 being listed as a main independent variable in the methods. The study likely analyzed PM2.5 but the abstract does not present those specific results. Full text review would be needed to confirm whether PM2.5 effects on respiratory hospitalizations were analyzed and reported.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure and COPD hospitalizations. It uses generalized additive models with distributed lag models, reports quantitative effect estimates (percent increases in daily admissions), and analyzes PM2.5 among other pollutants. COPD hospitalizations qualify as respiratory hospitalizations. The abstract indicates effect estimates are reported, though confidence intervals are not explicitly mentioned in the abstract.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is one of the exposures analyzed, (3) the outcome is respiratory hospitalizations, (4) it uses a case-crossover design, (5) it reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals (1.73% increase, 95% CI: 1.34%, 2.12% for PM2.5), and (6) it is published in English. The study also examines PM2.5-10, but PM2.5 is explicitly included as a separate exposure, which meets the inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original ecological time-series study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalizations (pneumonia, acute bronchitis, bronchiolitis, and asthma), (4) study design is time-series using generalized additive Poisson regression, (5) reports relative risks with values at multiple lags (RR=1.017 at lag 2, RR=1.022 at lag 5, RR=1.020 at lag 7), and (6) published in English (with Portuguese translation included). The study uses appropriate time-series methodology with lag structures and controlling for confounders.

The study meets most inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospital admissions with quantitative RR estimates and CIs. However, the study design is a difference-in-differences approach with distributed lag non-linear models, which is neither a traditional time-series nor case-crossover design as specified in the inclusion criteria. While difference-in-differences applied to daily data across multiple regions shares similarities with time-series analysis, it represents a distinct methodological approach. This ambiguity regarding study design qualification warrants expert review.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is analyzed as one of multiple exposures, (3) outcome is respiratory emergency department visits, (4) case-crossover design is explicitly stated, (5) reports positive associations (effect estimates) for PM2.5 across different lags and respiratory conditions, and (6) published in English. The abstract describes quantitative results for PM2.5 associations with both COPD and upper respiratory disease ED visits.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original time-series epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations (acute lower respiratory infections including CAP, AECB, AECOPD, AEB). It reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals (percent increases per 10-μg/m3 increase in PM2.5). The study is clearly published in English.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure and hospital admissions across multiple disease categories, including respiratory diseases. The study reports quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals (e.g., percent change in admissions per 10-μg/m3 increase in PM2.5). Although it examines multiple outcomes beyond respiratory hospitalizations, respiratory hospitalizations are explicitly included as one of the 7 major disease categories analyzed. The study meets all inclusion criteria: original epidemiological study, PM2.5 exposure, respiratory hospitalization outcome (among others), time-series design, and reports effect estimates with CIs.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study using time-series design with generalized additive model of Poisson regression; (2) PM2.5 is one of the exposures analyzed (alongside PM2.5-bound PAH); (3) Outcome is respiratory emergency department visits for asthma; (4) Reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals; (5) Appears to be published in English. The study examines daily counts of ERVs using time-series methods, which fits the specified study design.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study; (2) exposure includes PM2.5; (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalizations; (4) time-series design explicitly stated; (5) reports percentage change with 95% CI for PM2.5 (0.755%; 95% CI: 0.422, 1.089%); (6) published in English. The study analyzes both PM2.5 and PM10, which is acceptable per inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) includes PM2.5 as exposure, (3) outcome is asthma-related emergency department visits (AEDv) which qualifies as respiratory ED visits, (4) uses time-series design with Poisson regression, (5) reports relative risks with specific quantitative estimates (4.4% increase per IQR of PM2.5), and (6) published in English. Although multiple pollutants were analyzed, PM2.5 is explicitly included with separate effect estimates.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly studied as one of the exposures, (3) Outcome is asthma-related hospital admissions and emergency department visits (respiratory hospitalizations), (4) Case-crossover design is clearly stated, (5) Results mention associations and 95% confidence intervals indicating effect estimates are reported, (6) Published in English. While the study examines multiple pollutants and effect modification, PM2.5 is specifically analyzed for both warm and cool seasons.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) It is an original epidemiological study using generalized additive models (GAM), which is characteristic of time-series design; (2) PM2.5 is specifically examined as an exposure; (3) Respiratory hospitalizations are among the outcomes analyzed; (4) The GAM approach with lag structures indicates a time-series design; (5) Quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs are reported (1.03% increase per 10 μg/m3 PM2.5 for respiratory HAs, 95% CI: 0.50%-1.56%); (6) The abstract is in English. Although the study examines multiple outcomes beyond respiratory, it specifically includes respiratory hospitalizations with quantitative estimates, making it relevant for the systematic review.

This is an original time-series epidemiological study examining PM2.5 (among other exposures) and includes respiratory hospital admissions as an outcome. The abstract mentions 'respiratory outcomes' and 'emergency admissions to hospital' with effect estimates and confidence intervals reported. Although the specific quantitative results for PM2.5 and respiratory hospitalizations are not detailed in the abstract, the study design, exposures, outcomes, and analytical approach meet the inclusion criteria.

This is an original time-series study using GAMs to assess short-term effects of PM2.5 (among other pollutants) on multiple cause-specific hospitalizations including respiratory diseases. The study reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs. Although it examines multiple disease categories, it explicitly reports effects on respiratory system hospitalizations (NO2 effect: 1.36%, 95%CI: 0.74-1.98%) and PM2.5 effects on overall hospitalizations. The study meets all inclusion criteria: original epidemiological study, includes PM2.5 exposure, includes respiratory hospitalizations as one outcome, uses time-series design with GAMs, reports effect estimates with CIs, and is in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study analyzing clinical records; (2) PM2.5 exposure explicitly measured and analyzed; (3) respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits for asthma exacerbations as outcomes; (4) time-series study design using Poisson regression; (5) reports relative risk with 95% CI for PM2.5 effects; (6) published in English. The study provides quantitative effect estimates (RR=1.24 for ED admissions, RR=1.31 for hospitalizations at lag0-1) with confidence intervals.

While this is an original time-series study examining respiratory ED visits with effect estimates reported, the primary exposures of interest are precipitation and temperature on thunderstorm days, not PM2.5. Although PM2.5 was included as a covariate in the model and the results explicitly state that 'Daily maximum O3 and PM2.5 levels were not significantly associated with asthma ED visits on thunderstorm days,' PM2.5 is not the main exposure being investigated. The study does not report effect estimates for the association between PM2.5 and respiratory ED visits.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design with generalized additive model; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures examined; (3) the outcome is respiratory hospitalizations (acute lower respiratory tract infections including pneumonia and bronchitis); (4) the study design is clearly time-series; (5) it reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals for PM2.5 and other pollutants; (6) the abstract is in English. Although multiple pollutants are examined, PM2.5 is specifically analyzed and reported with quantitative effect estimates.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure (along with PM10), reports respiratory hospitalizations (asthma and COPD) as outcomes, provides odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals, and appears to be published in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study using time-series design with Poisson regression; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures; (3) Respiratory hospital admissions are reported as an outcome; (4) Time-series design analyzing daily counts; (5) Reports relative risk with 95% CI for respiratory admissions associated with PM2.5 (7.5% [4.9-10.2%] per 12.4 μg/m3 increase); (6) Published in English. Although the study also examines ultrafine particles, PM2.5 is analyzed separately with quantitative effect estimates for respiratory hospitalizations.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design with multi-level Poisson regression; exposure is PM2.5; outcome is respiratory hospital admissions; quantitative effect estimates are reported (8.6%, 6.2%, and 4.1% increases in hospitalization rates per 10 μg/m3 increase in PM2.5); and it is published in English. The study provides clear relative risk estimates for the PM2.5-respiratory hospitalization association.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a time-stratified case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure, reports respiratory hospitalizations as an outcome, provides quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals (1.74% increase per 10 μg/m3, 95% CI: 1.41-2.07%), and appears to be published in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure, includes respiratory hospitalizations as an outcome, reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CI (1.95% increase per 10 μg/m3 PM2.5 for respiratory diseases), and appears to be published in English.

While this is a time-series study examining respiratory hospitalizations with effect estimates, the primary exposure is particle oxidative potential (OP), not PM2.5 mass concentration itself. The study uses PM2.5 as a carrier measure to calculate oxidative potential (OP expressed as % loss per m³), but the actual exposure variable being analyzed is the oxidative capacity of particles, not PM2.5 concentration. This does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring PM2.5 as the exposure.

This is an original epidemiological study examining fine particulate matter (PM2.5) exposure and emergency department visits for pediatric asthma. It uses a time-series design with Poisson generalized linear models, reports rate ratios with 95% confidence intervals, and meets all inclusion criteria. The study focuses on source-specific PM2.5 components, which is still PM2.5 exposure.

This is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations. It uses a Generalized Additive Model (GAM), which is consistent with time-series analysis. The study reports quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals (e.g., 1.95% increase (0.25, 3.67) for PM2.5). All inclusion criteria are met: original research, PM2.5 exposure, respiratory hospitalization outcome, time-series design, and quantitative effect estimates with CI.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) It is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design, (2) exposure is PM2.5 from landscape fires, (3) outcome includes respiratory hospitalizations (specifically asthma), (4) study design is explicitly time-series, (5) reports risk ratios with 95% confidence intervals (e.g., RR 1.16, 95% CI 1.00 to 1.35 for asthma), and (6) published in English. Although the study also examines cardiovascular outcomes, it clearly includes respiratory hospitalizations as a primary outcome of interest.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using time-series analysis, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures analyzed, (3) the outcome is chronic respiratory disease (CRD) hospitalizations, (4) the study design is time-series, (5) it reports quantitative effect estimates (excess risks) with 95% confidence intervals for PM2.5 (2.13%, 95% CI: 0.55%, 3.74% per 10 μg/m3 increase), and (6) the abstract is in English. While multiple pollutants are analyzed, PM2.5 is specifically examined which satisfies the exposure criterion.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using case-crossover design, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome is respiratory healthcare visits (hospitalization/ED visits) for asthma, LRTI, and URTI, (4) uses case-crossover design, (5) reports odds ratios with effect estimates for PM2.5 increases, and (6) published in English. The study explicitly mentions 'respiratory-related healthcare visits' which encompasses hospitalizations and ED visits.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) It is an original epidemiological study using a time-stratified case-crossover design, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures analyzed, (3) the outcome is hospitalization for respiratory diseases in children, (4) it uses a case-crossover study design, (5) it reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals for PM2.5 (OR=1.017, 95%CI: 1.003-1.031), and (6) the abstract is in English. The study examines multiple pollutants including PM2.5, which is acceptable under the inclusion criteria.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure (among other exposures) and asthma exacerbations resulting in ED and inpatient visits. The study reports rate ratios with confidence intervals. Although the abstract emphasizes effect modification by viral infections and only shows RRs for grass pollen in the excerpt, the title and methods clearly indicate PM2.5 was analyzed as an exposure. The outcome includes both ED and inpatient (hospitalization) visits for asthma exacerbation, which are respiratory hospitalizations/ED visits meeting inclusion criteria.

This study meets the inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using time-series analysis (GAM on daily data) examining PM2.5 exposure (among other pollutants) and respiratory hospitalizations (patients with comorbid respiratory diseases). It reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs (7.25% increase per 10 μg/m3 PM2.5). Although the population is restricted to patients with diabetes mellitus comorbidity, the outcome is still respiratory hospitalization, which meets the inclusion criteria.

While this is a time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure with quantitative effect estimates, the outcome is acute upper respiratory tract infections (AURTIs), which typically refers to infections of the upper respiratory system (common cold, pharyngitis, sinusitis, etc.) rather than lower respiratory conditions that are the primary focus of respiratory hospitalizations in such reviews. Upper respiratory tract infections are distinct from conditions like pneumonia, COPD exacerbations, asthma, or other lower respiratory diseases that typically drive respiratory hospitalization studies. The review likely targets lower respiratory outcomes.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using time-series design, (2) examines PM2.5 exposure (among other PM fractions), (3) outcome is emergency department visits for asthma (a respiratory condition), (4) time-series study design explicitly stated, (5) reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals for the association between PM2.5 increases and asthma visits, and (6) published in English. Although the outcome is specifically asthma ED visits rather than all respiratory hospitalizations, asthma is a respiratory condition and ED visits represent acute care utilization comparable to hospitalizations for systematic review purposes.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study analyzing data from 249 Korean communities, (2) exposure is PM2.5 explicitly stated, (3) outcome includes respiratory hospitalizations, (4) uses case time-series analysis which is a variant of time-series design, (5) reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CI (1.43% increase per 10 μg/m³ PM2.5 increment for respiratory hospitalization with CI: 1.34%, 1.52%), and (6) published in English. Although the study also examines cardiovascular outcomes, it explicitly includes respiratory hospitalizations as a primary outcome.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalization (COPD admissions), (4) case-crossover design, (5) reports effect estimate with 95% CI (1.6%, 95% CI: 0.6%, 2.7% per 10 μg/m3 increase), and (6) published in English. No exclusion criteria apply.

While this study examines PM2.5 among other pollutants using a case-crossover design with effect estimates, the outcome is 'pediatric asthma visit treated with prednisone' rather than hospitalization or ED visit specifically. The results section explicitly states 'We observed no such associations with accumulation mode particles, black carbon, fine particles (≤2.5μm), or sulfur dioxide,' indicating no significant association was found for PM2.5. The primary exposure of interest is ultrafine particles, not PM2.5. The outcome definition is ambiguous and may include outpatient visits rather than strictly hospitalizations or ED visits.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using case-crossover design, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of multiple exposures, (3) outcome is respiratory hospital admissions, (4) case-crossover study design is clearly stated, (5) the abstract indicates effect estimates were computed showing 'adverse relationships' and mentions effect strength, suggesting quantitative measures were reported, and (6) published in English. While multiple pollutants were analyzed, PM2.5 is specifically included and shows significant effects in 2-pollutant models.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalization (COPD hospitalizations), (4) case-crossover study design, (5) reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals, and (6) appears to be in English. The study specifically examines PM2.5-COPD hospitalization associations with quantitative effect estimates.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) exposure includes PM2.5, (3) outcome includes respiratory hospitalizations (916,388 respiratory admissions), (4) case-crossover design explicitly stated in title and methods (conditional logistic regression), (5) reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs (0.26% increase per 10 μg/m³ PM2.5 for respiratory admissions, 95% CI = 0.22%, 0.31%), and (6) published in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) It is an original epidemiological study using quasi-Poisson regression with distributed lag model, which is characteristic of time-series designs; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures analyzed; (3) The outcome is respiratory hospital admissions (asthma, COPD, bronchiectasis); (4) The methodology describes a time-series approach using aggregated data from 2008-2018 with control for temporal trends and seasonality; (5) Relative risks with 95% confidence intervals are reported for PM2.5 associations; (6) The abstract is in English. Although multiple air pollutants were examined, PM2.5 results are specifically reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure, reports respiratory hospitalizations (pneumonia) as the outcome, and provides quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals (12% and 4% increases in admissions).

The primary exposure is coarse particles (PM2.5-10), not PM2.5. Although PM2.5 is mentioned in the abstract as an adjustment variable, the main focus is on coarse particles. This does not meet the inclusion criteria requiring PM2.5 as the primary exposure of interest.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using time-series design; (2) PM2.5 is analyzed as one of multiple exposures; (3) outcome is hospital admissions for asthma, which is a respiratory hospitalization; (4) time-series study design explicitly stated and GAM methodology described; (5) reports relative risk with 95% CI for PM2.5 (RR=1.015, 95% CI: 1.003-1.028 per 10 μg/m3); (6) published in English. Asthma hospitalizations are a specific type of respiratory hospitalization and are appropriate for inclusion.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study; (2) PM2.5 is analyzed as one of the exposures; (3) Outcome includes both respiratory ED visits and hospitalizations for COPD exacerbation; (4) Time-series study design using Poisson regression; (5) Reports relative risks with confidence intervals (p-values provided); (6) Published in English. COPD exacerbation is a respiratory outcome appropriate for this review.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design, examines PM2.5 exposure (along with ozone), reports respiratory emergency department visits as the outcome, provides rate ratios with 95% credible intervals, and appears to be published in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is source-specific PM2.5, (3) outcome includes respiratory emergency department visits, (4) case-crossover design, (5) reports excess risk (equivalent to relative risk) with 95% confidence intervals for respiratory outcomes, and (6) published in English. Although it also examines cardiovascular outcomes, the respiratory ED visits are clearly analyzed and reported.

This is an original time-series study that examined PM2.5 (among other pollutants) and asthma hospitalizations. The study used generalized additive models with distributed lag models and reports effect estimates. Asthma hospitalizations are a respiratory hospitalization outcome. Although PM2.5 is analyzed alongside other pollutants, it is explicitly mentioned in the results as being associated with disease burden, meeting inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using time-series analysis with DLNM; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures analyzed; (3) the outcome is hospital admissions for respiratory diseases; (4) the study design is time-series; (5) quantitative effect estimates are reported (RR 1.089, 95% CI 1.001-1.183 for PM2.5); (6) the article is in English. Although multiple pollutants are examined, PM2.5 is specifically analyzed and reported with effect estimates.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using time-series design with generalized additive models, (2) PM2.5 is one of the exposures analyzed, (3) outcome is hospital admissions for acute bronchitis which is a respiratory hospitalization, (4) time-series study design, (5) reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs (1.23% increase per 10 µg/m3 PM2.5, 95% CI 0.21-2.26%), and (6) published in English. The fact that multiple pollutants were analyzed does not exclude the study as PM2.5 effects are reported separately.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using time-series design, examines PM2.5 as one of multiple exposures, focuses on asthma emergency department visits (respiratory outcome), reports rate ratios (RRs) as effect estimates, and appears to be published in English. While it examines multiple pollutants, PM2.5 is explicitly included in the analysis.

This study meets several inclusion criteria: it examines PM2.5 (fine particulate matter) as one exposure, has respiratory hospitalizations as outcome, and uses time-series design (generalized additive Poisson regression with daily data). However, the abstract only reports effect estimates for temperature (18% increase in risk for 4°C increase), not for PM2.5. The study analyzed PM2.5 in multivariate models but the abstract does not provide the PM2.5 effect estimate with confidence interval, which is required for inclusion. Without access to the full text to verify if PM2.5 results are reported, the decision remains uncertain.

This is an original time-series study examining both PM2.5 and ozone exposure in relation to cardiorespiratory outcomes including respiratory disease and asthma/wheeze, using both ED visits and hospital admissions. The study reports quantitative risk ratios with specific values mentioned (e.g., 1.020, 1.004 for respiratory disease-ozone). While the primary focus appears to be comparing different visit types as a methodological question, it meets all inclusion criteria: original epidemiological study, PM2.5 exposure analyzed, respiratory outcomes (hospitalizations and ED visits), time-series design, and reports effect estimates.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using case time series design, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcomes include both respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits, (4) case time series is an acceptable study design similar to time-series, (5) reports excess relative risk with 95% confidence intervals for respiratory outcomes (1.34% for respiratory ED visits, and mentions associations for respiratory hospitalizations), and (6) published in English. The study examines multiple outcomes but includes the specific respiratory outcomes of interest.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) includes PM2.5 as an exposure (among other pollutants), (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalization (COPD exacerbations requiring hospital admission), (4) uses case-crossover design (time-stratified), (5) reports rate ratios with 95% CIs (RR=1.030, 95% CI 1.006-1.055 for PM2.5), and (6) published in English.

This is an original time-series epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations (among other outcomes). The study explicitly states it examined respiratory hospital admissions, used a time-series design with generalized linear models, and reports associations (effect estimates) between PM2.5 and respiratory admissions. While it also examines cardiovascular outcomes, the inclusion of respiratory hospitalizations meets the criteria. The study analyzes source-specific PM2.5 components, which still represents PM2.5 exposure.

This is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 (among other pollutants) and respiratory ED visits for pediatric asthma. The study uses a time-series design (generalized additive model with distributed lag model applied to daily ED visits), reports quantitative effect estimates (RR with 95% CI), and is published in English. Asthma ED visits are a respiratory outcome meeting the inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study; (2) PM2.5 is analyzed as one of multiple exposures; (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalization (asthma admissions); (4) study design is time-series (title mentions case-crossover but abstract describes time-series analysis); (5) reports rate ratios with 95% CIs (RR=1.014, 95%CI: 1.000-1.028 for PM2.5); (6) published in English. Asthma hospitalization is a respiratory hospitalization outcome.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using time-series regression analysis, (2) includes PM2.5 as an exposure among multiple pollutants, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalization (ALRI, pneumonia, bronchiolitis), (4) time-series study design, (5) reports relative risk with 95% CI for PM2.5 (RR=1.089, 95%CI:1.075-1.103), and (6) published in English. Although multiple pollutants were analyzed, PM2.5 is explicitly included and analyzed separately with quantitative estimates.

This is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations (including asthma) using time-series methodology with Poisson regression. The study reports percentage increases with 95% confidence intervals for respiratory outcomes. While it also examines cardiovascular outcomes, it clearly includes respiratory hospitalizations as a primary outcome. The study design is consistent with time-series analysis with lag days and temporal adjustments.

This is an original time-series epidemiological study examining PM2.5 (among other pollutants) and respiratory emergency department visits in children. Although the study found no significant association between PM2.5 and ER admissions, it meets all inclusion criteria: it examines PM2.5 exposure, respiratory ED visits as outcome, uses time-series design with Poisson regression models, and reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs. The null finding for PM2.5 is still a valid result for systematic review inclusion.

While this study uses PM2.5 as an exposure measure and examines respiratory hospitalizations among other outcomes using an interrupted time series design, it focuses on long-term effects (8 years) following a specific event rather than the short-term associations between PM2.5 fluctuations and respiratory hospitalizations typical of time-series studies. The study design is interrupted time series comparing pre/post fire periods rather than examining day-to-day or time-varying PM2.5-hospitalization associations. Additionally, the abstract does not clearly indicate whether specific effect estimates with confidence intervals for the PM2.5-respiratory hospitalization relationship are reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using time-series design, (2) PM2.5 (including organic carbon fraction) is one of the exposures analyzed, (3) outcome is respiratory ED visits (pneumonia, bronchitis/bronchiolitis, URI), (4) time-series design explicitly stated, (5) reports percentage increases with 95% confidence intervals that can be converted to effect estimates, and (6) published in English. Although multiple pollutants were examined, PM2.5 components were specifically analyzed.

The study examines hospitalizations for pulmonary embolism and venous thrombosis (cardiovascular/thrombotic outcomes), not respiratory hospitalizations. Additionally, the exposure is PM10, not PM2.5. The outcome does not meet inclusion criteria.

The study examines suicide deaths as the outcome, not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. Additionally, the exposure is PM10, not PM2.5. The study fails to meet both the exposure criterion (PM2.5) and the outcome criterion (respiratory hospitalization/ED visit).

This study fails multiple inclusion criteria: (1) it is a critical review, not an original epidemiological study, (2) the exposure is PM10, not PM2.5, and (3) the outcome is mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits.

This is a systematic review/literature review of other studies, not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is coronary/cardiovascular disease, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. The exposure includes PM10 but does not specifically report PM2.5 data.
This is a meta-analysis/systematic review, not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is mortality (not hospitalization/ED visits), and the exposure is PM10 (not PM2.5).

Although this is an original epidemiological study with PM2.5 exposure, case-crossover design, and quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals, the outcome is out-of-hospital cardiac arrest (OHCA) of cardiac origin, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visit. This does not meet the inclusion criteria for outcomes.

This is an animal experimental study (mice) testing a pharmaceutical intervention (Astragaloside IV), not an epidemiological study examining the association between PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations in humans. The study design is an experimental laboratory study, not time-series or case-crossover. The outcome is mechanistic lung injury markers, not hospitalizations or ED visits.

This is explicitly stated to be a review ('this review is focused on these aspects') rather than an original epidemiological study. It discusses historical backgrounds, physicochemical characteristics, and pathological roles of particulate matter, but does not present original data with quantitative effect estimates for PM2.5 and respiratory hospitalizations.

The study examines PM10 (particulate matter ≤10 μm) as the exposure, not PM2.5 (≤2.5 μm). While the outcome (respiratory hospitalizations for COPD and asthma) and study design (time-series) meet inclusion criteria, the exposure does not match the required PM2.5. PM10 is a different size fraction of particulate matter and cannot be considered equivalent to PM2.5.

While this study includes a multisite time-series analysis component examining PM2.5 constituents and appears to report effect estimates, the primary outcome is cardiovascular hospital admissions, not respiratory hospitalizations. The abstract specifically mentions 'cardiovascular hospital admissions' as the outcome and does not mention respiratory outcomes. This fails the outcome inclusion criterion.

The study examines PM10 (particulate matter ≤10 μm) rather than PM2.5 (≤2.5 μm) as the exposure. While the study design (time-series with Poisson regression) is appropriate and it reports effect estimates with confidence intervals for hospital admissions, the exposure does not meet the inclusion criteria which specifically requires PM2.5 or fine particulate matter ≤2.5 μm.

Study examines PM10 (particles ≤10 µm), not PM2.5 (particles ≤2.5 µm) as required by inclusion criteria. While the study design is case-crossover, has respiratory hospitalizations as outcome, and reports quantitative effect estimates, the exposure does not meet the PM2.5 requirement.

This study examines PM10 (particles ≤10 µm) rather than PM2.5 (particles ≤2.5 µm) as the exposure variable. While the study meets other inclusion criteria (original epidemiological study, time-series design, respiratory hospitalizations as outcome, reports RR with confidence intervals, published in English), the exposure does not match the required PM2.5 specification. PM10 and PM2.5 are distinct particle size fractions with different health effects and sources.

This appears to be a health impact assessment or policy evaluation study rather than an original epidemiological study. The abstract states that 'a literature review was carried out to determine the appropriate relative risk to be used in the estimations' and that 'public health gains were calculated based on the selected relative risks', indicating that the study applied existing effect estimates from other studies rather than conducting an original analysis to derive new effect estimates from primary data. This does not meet the inclusion criterion of being an original epidemiological study that reports its own effect measures.

The study examines PM10 (particles <10 µm) rather than PM2.5 (particles ≤2.5 µm) as the exposure. Additionally, the outcome is emergency ambulance dispatches, not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits specifically. While respiratory diseases are mentioned, the primary outcome reported is general non-traumatic ambulance dispatches, and respiratory-specific effect estimates are noted as non-significant without specific quantitative measures provided.

Although this is an original epidemiological study with a case-crossover design examining PM2.5 exposure and reporting effect estimates with confidence intervals, the outcome is ischemic stroke hospitalization, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visit. This does not meet the inclusion criteria for outcome.

This study examines cardiovascular events (CVEs), not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. Additionally, the exposure is PM10, not PM2.5. The study fails to meet both the exposure criterion (requires PM2.5) and the outcome criterion (requires respiratory hospitalizations/ED visits).

This study examines cardiovascular mortality as the outcome, not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. While the study uses a time-series design (distributed lag model) and reports quantitative associations, it does not meet the inclusion criteria for outcome type. Additionally, the study focuses on PM10 rather than PM2.5, and the primary outcome is mortality rather than hospitalization.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria specify original epidemiological studies only, and explicitly exclude reviews and meta-analyses. Additionally, the outcome is mortality (all-cause, cardiovascular, respiratory, and cerebrovascular mortality), not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits as required.

This is a literature review/book chapter that summarizes existing studies rather than an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is mortality, not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits.

While this study meets several inclusion criteria (original epidemiological study, PM2.5 exposure, case-crossover design, reports effect estimates with confidence intervals), it must be excluded because the outcome is myocardial infarction (MI) mortality, which is a cardiovascular outcome, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visit as required by the inclusion criteria.

Although this is an original case-crossover study that includes PM2.5 exposure and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, the outcome is stroke hospitalization (cardiovascular), not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. This does not meet the outcome inclusion criteria.

The study examines PM10 (coarse particulate matter) from mineral dust, not PM2.5 (fine particulate matter ≤2.5 µm). The outcome is respiratory symptoms (cough) rather than respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits. These are critical mismatches with the inclusion criteria.

While this is an original epidemiological study using interrupted time-series analysis examining respiratory hospital visits with effect estimates reported, the primary exposure is PM10 (not PM2.5). The study evaluates the effect of a vegetation burning ban on hospital visits, with PM10 as the measured air pollutant. PM2.5 is not mentioned in the abstract as being analyzed or measured, which fails to meet the inclusion criterion requiring PM2.5 exposure.

The outcome is ischemic stroke hospitalizations, not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. The exposure is coarse particulate matter (PM10-2.5), not PM2.5. Both the exposure and outcome fail to meet the inclusion criteria.

While this study examines PM2.5 exposure using a time-series design and reports quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals, the outcome is respiratory mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. The inclusion criteria specifically require respiratory hospitalization/ED visits as the outcome.

This is a systematic literature review/meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The title explicitly states it is a 'systematic literature review' and the abstract describes reviewing 34 articles following PRISMA guidelines. This violates inclusion criterion 1 and meets the first exclusion criterion.

This study examines PM10 (not PM2.5) as the exposure and mortality (not hospitalization or ED visits) as the outcome. The study fails to meet both the exposure criterion (PM2.5) and outcome criterion (respiratory hospitalization/ED visit).

While this is an original epidemiological study using appropriate study designs (time-series and case-crossover) with quantitative effect estimates, it fails to meet two critical inclusion criteria: (1) the exposure is PM10, not PM2.5, and (2) the outcome is respiratory mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits.

The study examines PM10 (not PM2.5) as the exposure and years of life lost (YLL) from respiratory mortality (not hospitalization or ED visits) as the outcome. Both the exposure and outcome do not meet the inclusion criteria.

This is a meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria specifically require original epidemiological studies and exclude meta-analyses. Additionally, the outcomes focus on mortality (respiratory, cardiovascular, etc.) rather than respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits.

The study examines PM10 (≤10µm) and NO2 as exposures, not PM2.5 (≤2.5µm). While the study does examine respiratory hospitalizations as an outcome and uses appropriate study designs (time-series with Poisson regression and case-crossover for mortality), it does not meet the critical inclusion criterion of PM2.5 exposure.

The study examines PM10 and ozone exposure, not PM2.5. The outcome is mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. Both the exposure and outcome do not meet the inclusion criteria.
Study examines PM10 exposure (not PM2.5) and mortality outcome (not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits). Both exposure and outcome fail to meet inclusion criteria.

While this is a time-series study with effect estimates, it does not examine PM2.5 as an exposure (only PM10, NO2, and SO2 are mentioned). Additionally, the outcome is respiratory disease mortality rather than respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits, which does not meet the inclusion criteria.

This study examines coarse particulate matter (PM2.5-10), not PM2.5 as required. Additionally, the outcome is mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. While the study design is time-series and provides effect estimates, it fails to meet two critical inclusion criteria regarding exposure (PM2.5) and outcome (respiratory hospitalization/ED visit).

The study examines PM10 (not PM2.5) as the exposure and mortality (not hospitalization or ED visits) as the outcome. While it uses an appropriate time-series design and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, it fails to meet the inclusion criteria for both exposure type (PM2.5 required) and outcome (respiratory hospitalization/ED visits required).

This study examines respiratory mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. Additionally, the exposure is PM10, not PM2.5. The study fails to meet inclusion criteria on both exposure (PM2.5 required) and outcome (respiratory hospitalization/ED visit required).

Study examines mortality (not hospitalization/ED visits) as the outcome. While it is a time-series study with effect estimates and includes PM10, the primary exposures are particle number concentration (PNC) and particle surface area concentration (PSC), not PM2.5. Most importantly, the outcome is cause-specific mortality rather than respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits, which fails the outcome inclusion criterion.

Study examines mortality as the outcome, not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. Additionally, the exposure is PM10, NO2, and O3, not PM2.5. Fails to meet both the exposure and outcome inclusion criteria.

This study should be excluded for two main reasons: (1) The exposure is PM10, not PM2.5 as required by the inclusion criteria, and (2) The outcome is mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visit. While the study is an original time-series epidemiological study with effect estimates, it does not meet the specific exposure and outcome criteria for this systematic review.

This study examines PM10 (not PM2.5) exposure and coronary heart disease hospitalization (not respiratory hospitalization). It fails to meet the inclusion criteria for both exposure type (requires PM2.5) and outcome (requires respiratory hospitalization/ED visit).

While this is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure, the outcome is mortality (all-cause, cardiovascular, and respiratory mortality), not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. The study also focuses on economic losses rather than reporting traditional epidemiological effect estimates like RR or OR for health outcomes.

The study examines coarse particulate matter (PM2.5-10, particles between 2.5-10 µm in diameter), not PM2.5 (fine particulate matter ≤2.5 µm). Additionally, the outcome is respiratory mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. Both the exposure and outcome do not meet the inclusion criteria.

The outcome is mortality (all-cause, cardiovascular, ischemic heart disease, respiratory/thoracic cancer mortality), not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. This does not meet the inclusion criteria requiring respiratory hospitalization/ED visit as the outcome.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. The study fails to meet inclusion criteria 1 (must be original study, not a review) and 3 (outcome must be respiratory hospitalization/ED visit).

Although this is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure and includes respiratory diseases in the analysis with effect estimates, the outcome is mortality (deaths) and years of life lost (YLL), not respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits. The study does not measure hospital admissions or ED visits, which are the required outcomes for this systematic review.

While this study meets several inclusion criteria (original epidemiological study, PM2.5 exposure, case-crossover design, reports effect estimates with CI), the outcome is mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visit. The systematic review specifically requires respiratory hospitalization/ED visit as the outcome.

The outcome is mortality (all-cause mortality), not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visit. The study examines PM2.5 exposure using appropriate study designs (time-series and case-crossover) with effect estimates, but does not meet the outcome inclusion criteria.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria explicitly require original epidemiological studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses. While the paper reviews studies on PM2.5 exposure and includes respiratory mortality as an outcome, the paper itself is a synthesis of other studies rather than primary research.

While this study meets several inclusion criteria (original epidemiological study, PM2.5 exposure, case-crossover design, reports effect estimates with CI), the outcome is respiratory mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visit. The systematic review specifically requires respiratory hospitalization/ED visit as the outcome.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria specifically require original studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses. Additionally, the outcome is mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits.

The study examines mortality as the outcome, not respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits. Although it uses PM2.5 exposure and a time-series design with effect estimates, the outcome does not meet the inclusion criteria which specifically requires respiratory hospitalization or ED visits.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria specifically require original studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses. While the underlying studies may have examined PM2.5 and respiratory outcomes, this publication itself is a synthesis of existing literature.

The study examines mortality as the outcome, not respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits. Although the study includes PM2.5 exposure, uses a time-series design (GAM), and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, it does not meet the inclusion criteria because the outcome is respiratory/cardiovascular/nonaccidental mortality rather than respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits.

Although this is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure with quantitative effect estimates, the outcome is mortality (all-cause, cardiovascular, and respiratory mortality), not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits as required by the inclusion criteria.

This is a program report describing four integrated studies including time-series epidemiologic studies (Ito and Thurston studies), animal exposure studies (Chen study), and in-vitro/in-vivo toxicologic studies (Gordon study). While it mentions PM2.5 exposure and a time-series component, the outcomes described are mortality and 'morbidity' without specific mention of respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. Additionally, this appears to be an overview/program report rather than a single original epidemiological study with reported effect estimates for respiratory hospitalization outcomes. The inclusion of animal and in-vitro studies as major components also makes this unsuitable for the review.

This is a meta-analysis/pooled analysis comparing analytical methods, not an original epidemiological study. The outcomes are mortality (deaths due to natural causes, cardiovascular disease, cerebrovascular disease and respiratory disease), not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. While PM2.5 is one of the exposures examined and time-series design is used, the study fails to meet the inclusion criteria for both study type (criterion 1) and outcome (criterion 3).

The study examines ozone exposure (not PM2.5 as primary exposure) and mortality outcomes (not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits). While the study design is time-series and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, it fails to meet the core inclusion criteria for exposure type and outcome measure.

The study examines mortality as the outcome, not respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits. While the study meets other criteria (original epidemiological study, PM2.5 exposure, time-series design, effect estimates reported), the outcome does not match the inclusion criteria which specifically requires respiratory hospitalization or ED visits.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis (not an original epidemiological study), and the outcome is heart failure hospitalization/incidence/mortality rather than respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. Fails inclusion criteria 1 and 3.

This is explicitly stated to be a review article ('have been described in this review'), not an original epidemiological study. Reviews are excluded per the inclusion criteria which require original epidemiological studies.

This is explicitly a review article ('In this review, we synthesize the scientific evidence...'), not an original epidemiological study. Reviews are specifically excluded in the exclusion criteria. Additionally, the outcomes discussed are broad (birth outcomes, respiratory systems, immune status, brain development, cardiometabolic health) rather than specifically respiratory hospitalization or ED visits.

This is a scoping review, not an original epidemiological study. It reviews 364 articles on climate change and neurologic health. The outcomes are neurologic diseases (stroke, dementia, Parkinson disease, MS) rather than respiratory hospitalizations. Fails multiple inclusion criteria.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The title explicitly states 'systematic review and meta-analysis' and the abstract describes searching and pooling multiple studies. This violates the first inclusion criterion requiring original epidemiological studies and meets the first exclusion criterion for reviews and meta-analyses.

This is explicitly stated as a review article examining cellular mechanisms of PM2.5-induced cell death. It does not report on respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits, does not use a time-series or case-crossover design, and does not provide epidemiological effect estimates.

This is a meta-analysis/systematic review, not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is myocardial infarction (MI), not respiratory hospitalization or ED visit. Fails inclusion criteria 1 and 3.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria specifically require original epidemiological studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses. Although the paper examines PM2.5 exposure and includes hospital utilization as an outcome, it synthesizes results from multiple studies rather than presenting original data.
This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria specifically require original studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses.

This is explicitly described as a review article ('The current review investigate epidemiological and experimental findings from 2016 to 2021'), which violates inclusion criterion 1 requiring original epidemiological studies. Reviews are explicitly listed in the exclusion criteria.

This is explicitly stated to be a review article ('this review article was prepared', 'In this review, we focus on') focusing on PM2.5 and chronic kidney disease, not respiratory hospitalizations. It fails on multiple inclusion criteria: (1) it is a review, not an original study, (2) the outcome is kidney disease, not respiratory hospitalization/ED visits.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria explicitly require original studies and the exclusion criteria specifically exclude reviews and meta-analyses. Additionally, the outcome reported is respiratory mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits.
This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria specifically require original studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses.
This is explicitly a review article ('In this review, we discussed the latest epidemiological advances...'), not an original epidemiological study. Reviews are excluded per the inclusion criteria.

While this is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure with effect estimates, it fails multiple inclusion criteria: (1) the study design is a cohort study, not time-series or case-crossover; (2) the primary outcome is mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. Although respiratory mortality is mentioned as a secondary outcome, the focus is on mortality rather than hospitalization/ED visits, which are distinct clinical endpoints.

This appears to be a narrative review, commentary, or editorial piece discussing the general health effects of wildfires and PM2.5. It does not present original epidemiological research, does not describe a specific study design (time-series or case-crossover), does not report quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals, and does not focus specifically on respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits as an outcome measure. The text discusses general health impacts and policy implications rather than presenting empirical study results.

This is explicitly a review article ('In this review, we summarize...') examining toxicological mechanisms of PM2.5 on vascular endothelial cells. It does not report original epidemiological research on respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. The outcome focus is on vascular endothelial cell toxicity, not respiratory hospitalizations.

This is a rapid review/systematic review of existing literature (not an original epidemiological study). The title explicitly states 'Quick review' and the methods describe reviewing 450 manuscripts of which 15 met inclusion criteria. This violates inclusion criterion #1 and meets the first exclusion criterion.

This is a meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is respiratory disease mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits as required by the inclusion criteria.

This is explicitly a review article as stated in the title ('A review of implications for human health'). It does not present original epidemiological research, does not report specific effect estimates with confidence intervals, and does not describe respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits as outcomes. It discusses general health impacts and chronic diseases rather than acute care utilization.

This is a review article (explicitly stated as 'This review summarizes and discusses studies') focused on neurological outcomes (Alzheimer's disease and dementia), not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. It does not meet the inclusion criteria for study type (must be original epidemiological study) or outcome (must be respiratory hospitalization/ED visit).

This is a meta-analysis (not an original epidemiological study) examining the association between PM2.5 and myocardial infarction hospitalizations (cardiovascular outcome, not respiratory). Fails inclusion criteria 1 (not original study) and 3 (outcome is cardiovascular, not respiratory).

This is a systematic review (not an original epidemiological study) examining the association between air pollution and ocular surface disease (conjunctivitis, dry eye, blepharitis), not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. Fails inclusion criteria 1 and 3.

This is a review article (explicitly stated as 'In this review') focusing on cardiovascular effects and vascular smooth muscle cells, not an original epidemiological study examining respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. It does not meet the inclusion criteria for study type or outcome.

This article focuses on cancer outcomes rather than respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. The title and abstract emphasize cancer risks and cancer mortality as primary outcomes. Additionally, the descriptive nature and inclusion of mitigation strategies suggest this may be a review or commentary rather than an original epidemiological study. The study design does not appear to be time-series or case-crossover.

This is explicitly a review article (stated in title and abstract), not an original epidemiological study. The outcome is cardiac developmental toxicity/congenital heart defects, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. Multiple exclusion criteria are met.

This is a review article of in vitro and in vivo experimental studies, not an original epidemiological study. It explicitly states 'The aim of this review is to provide a brief overview of in vitro and in vivo experimental studies.' Reviews are excluded per inclusion criteria #1, and animal/in-vitro studies are explicitly excluded.

This is explicitly described as a review article ('This review aims to summarize and discuss...'), not an original epidemiological study. It does not meet inclusion criterion 1 and meets the first exclusion criterion for reviews.

This is a review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is mortality (not hospitalization/ED visit), and the study design is long-term cohort studies (not time-series or case-crossover). Fails multiple inclusion criteria.
